instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-3476: What is 820-3476? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.PP1V35_S3: What is PP1V35_S3? PP1V35_S3 is a 1.35v power rail present when the machine is in an S3 suspend to RAM state.
definitions.PPBUS_G3H: What is PPBUS_G3H? Main system power rail that charges the battery, or is power from the battery, that everything else is powered from. .
definitions.PP3V3_S5: What is PP3V3_S5? PP3V3_S5 is a 3.3v power rail when the system is in an S5 soft off power state.
definitions.PP5V_S5: What is PP5V_S5? This is a 5v power rail that is present when the machine is in an S5 soft off state..
definitions.PPVRTC_G3H: What is PPVRTC_G3H? PPVRTC_G3H is a 3.3v power rail for the RTC circuit present when the machine is in a G3H global system hardware off state. .
definitions.PP3V3_SUS: What is PP3V3_SUS? The "PP3V3_SUS" rail on a MacBook logic board is a power rail that provides a 3.3-volt supply to the suspend-to-RAM (S3 state) components. .
definitions.PP5V_S4: What is PP5V_S4? PP5V_S4 is a 5v power rail present when the machine is in an S4 suspend to disk state..
definitions.PP3V42_G3H: What is PP3V42_G3H? PP3V42_G3H is a power rail present when the machine is in a G3H global system hardware off state and is the first rail that should be generated in Macbooks that use it. .
definitions.PP3V3_S4: What is PP3V3_S4? The "PP3V3_S4" power rail in a MacBook is used to supply 3.3 volts to certain components when the system is in the S4 power state, also known as "suspend to disk" or "hibernate." This rail is active when the MacBook is not fully off but not in an awake state, allowing for faster startup times compared to a full boot sequence. The S4 power state means Suspend to Disk: This is a low-power state where the system context is saved to disk, allowing the system to be powered down almost entirely. Upon waking, the system can restore its state from the disk, effectively resuming where it left off..
definitions.PP1V05_SUS: What is PP1V05_SUS? The PP1V05_SUS signal in the MacBook schematic is a power rail that supplies 1.05 volts, typically used in a suspended (SUS) state of the laptop. This state is a low-power mode where essential system functions are maintained, but the majority of the system is powered down..
definitions.PPVTTDDR_S3: What is PPVTTDDR_S3? PPVTTDDR_S3 is a 3.3v power rail that powers the DDR RAM when the machine is in an S3 suspend to RAM state. .
definitions.PM_SLP_S4_L: What is PM_SLP_S4_L? PM_SLP_S4_L is a signal that puts the system into an S4 suspend to disk sleep state when it is low(_L means signal is asserted when voltage is low).
definitions.PM_SLP_S3_L: What is PM_SLP_S3_L? PM_SLP_S3_L puts the machine to sleep in an S3 state when it is asserted, the _L means it is asserted when it is low voltage. When this signal is 3.3v the machine will be asked to turn on S0 power rails and begin the bootup process.
definitions.CHGR_BMON: What is CHGR_BMON? CHGR_BMON goes between the ISL6259, ISL9239, or ISL9240 that charges the battery & creates PPBUS_G3H and the SMC(system management controller) or T2 chip(on machines where the SMC is integrated into the T2 chip) and provides current sensing information on battery charging to the SMC. If diagnostics reveal an off reading or failure with the charger current sense, this is a good place to start troubleshooting..
definitions.CHGR_AMON: What is CHGR_AMON? CHGR_AMON provides DC current sense information to the SMC(System management controller) or T2 chip(on machines where the SMC is integrated into the T2 chip). It comes from the battery charging chip that controls the laptop charger, battery charging, and creation of PPBUS_G3H(ISL6259, ISL9239, or ISL9240 chip depending on the logic board part number and model). This is used for sensors. If a DC current sense sensor is reading off in diagnostics, this is a place to start looking. .
definitions.PPDCIN_G3H_ISOL: What is PPDCIN_G3H_ISOL? This is the voltage coming directly from the charger after going through a transistor. .
definitions.PP3V3_S5_AVREF_SMC: What is PP3V3_S5_AVREF_SMC? PP3V3_S5_AVREF_SMC Is a reference voltage for the SMC’s voltage sensors & other sensors..
definitions.PM_SLP_S5_L: What is PM_SLP_S5_L? PM_SLP_S5_L is a signal that, when 3.3v, turns on power rails that will wake the system from an S5 state. This signal is a part of the power management system of the MacBook.  The \"PM\" prefix typically stands for \"Power Management,\" and the \"SLP\" is for \"Sleep.\" The \"S5\" denotes the specific sleep state, which is Suspend to Disk, and the \"_L\" suffix indicates that this is an active low signal..
definitions.5V_S5: What is 5V_S5? 5V_S5 is an abbreviation for “PP5V_S5” which is a 5v power rail that is present when the machine is in an S5 state. .

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3476</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> macbook pro
threads.message: a 3476 macbook pro it has the orange light on the charger and all the rails are present except <SIGNAL>SMC_SENSOR_PWR_EN</SIGNAL>.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3476</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> macbook pro
threads.message:
Can you explain what is the problem with this board?
No video, no USB activity???
Try to start in SMC bypass mode.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3476</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> macbook pro
threads.message:
The actual problem is that <SIGNAL>SMC_SENSOR_PWR_EN</SIGNAL> on pin2 of <TRANSISTOR>Q5480</TRANSISTOR> is missing
<TRANSISTOR>Q5480</TRANSISTOR> pin 3 is 0v, p4 12.58v and p5 12.4 and p6 12.58

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3476</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> macbook pro
threads.message:
"No video, no USB activity???
Try to start in SMC bypass mode."

The board is working and only missing <SIGNAL>SMC_SENSOR_PWR_EN</SIGNAL>???

Post the ALL then...

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3476</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> macbook pro

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3476</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> macbook pro

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3476</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> macbook pro
threads.message:
"8.85v"
Do you mean 8.58V???

"<SIGNAL>PP3V3_S4SW_SNS</SIGNAL>
<SIGNAL>PP1V35_S3</SIGNAL>
<SIGNAL>PP1V35_S3_CPUDDR</SIGNAL>
<SIGNAL>PPVTTDDR_S3</SIGNAL>"
You've posted other S4/3 voltages as present; so these ones should also be present.
Check for short on any of them.
An o-scope should help to catch a pulse at least, if present...

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3476</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> macbook pro
threads.message: I checked for a short but there is no short on these rails

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3476</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> macbook pro
threads.message:
Start then to check powers and enable for all these S3 supplies which don't deliver tension.
<SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S4_L</SIGNAL> is present, but some resistors derivate this signal to enable various supplies.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3476</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> macbook pro
threads.message: could it be that <TRANSISTOR>Q5480</TRANSISTOR> gone bad? because i get nothing on pin 1/2/3 and only on P4 12.58v p5 12.45 and p6  12.33v

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3476</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> macbook pro
threads.message:
When you have doubt about any sensor, try to start on SMC bypass.
As you got S4 voltages, board is starting.
Check if all coils pulse at least.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3476</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> macbook pro
threads.message:
Bypass SMC reffers to a way to start the board disabling SMC sensors.
And is explained in the results of the link above mentioned.
Press power button, plugin the charger and maintain power button pressed 5-10s...

threads.message:

and I really do appreciate your time and effort.
And I wish you a very nice weekend ahead.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3476</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> macbook pro
threads.message:
No problem, you can get help here anytime you need.
Happy weekend too...

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3476</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> macbook pro
threads.message:
Thanks a lot for your understanding.
the <SIGNAL>PP3V3_S4</SIGNAL> is present but <SIGNAL>PP3_V3_S4SW_SNS</SIGNAL> and <SIGNAL>PP1V35_S3</SIGNAL> are missing.
you suggested to check the S3 supplies to see which one is not creating tension,
S3 supplies are the same as S3 switches? where the S3 rail gets created?
when I measure the resistance  on <RESISTOR>R2221</RESISTOR> I get 0,558 kilo ohm but it should be 1kohm

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3476</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> macbook pro
threads.message:
<SIGNAL>PP3V3_S4SW_SNS</SIGNAL> is required for the SMC sensors.
Did you try SMC bypass?

S3 supplies should be controlled by <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S4_L</SIGNAL>.
S0 supplies are controlled by <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S3_L</SIGNAL>.
Take a look at page 61.

Measure a resistor onboard, when is connected with other components, is not the best idea.
There are more resistors with similar value; te result will be lower value...

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3476</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> macbook pro
threads.message:
Dear Sir it turns on when I bypass the SMC and fan spins very fast. but no image
what should I do next?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3476</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> macbook pro
threads.message:
Do you have USB activity?
Connect an USB mouse, and reconnect it when board is on; let see if gets light.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3476</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> macbook pro
threads.message: the USB is active and I get light even when I disconnect and connect it to the board

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3476</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> macbook pro
threads.message:
Seems that board boots in SMC bypass.
No image, nor backlight?
Try external monitor too.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3476</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> macbook pro
threads.message: no unfortunately nothing on external monitor not via HDMI nor Thunderbolt

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3476</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> macbook pro
threads.message:
Will be better to test USB with external OSX.
Need pendrive, or HDD adapter with link LED.
If flashes, means USB activity for sure; mouse can get confused.

Post values for <SIGNAL>CHGR_AMON</SIGNAL> and <SIGNAL>CHGR_BMON</SIGNAL>, whitout starting in bypass mode.
<SIGNAL>SMC_AVREF</SIGNAL> voltage is present?

threads.message:
<SIGNAL>CHGR_AMON</SIGNAL> is 0.089v and <SIGNAL>CHGR_BMON</SIGNAL> is 0.1V
I can't. find any the <SIGNAL>SMC_AVREF</SIGNAL> not in the schematics nor board view.
I tested with an external HDD the lights burns

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3476</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> macbook pro
threads.message:
"<SIGNAL>SMC_AVREF</SIGNAL> not in the schematics"
<SIGNAL>PP3V3_S5_AVREF_SMC</SIGNAL>

Post <SIGNAL>SMC_DCIN_VSENSE</SIGNAL> and <SIGNAL>PPDCIN_G3H_ISOL</SIGNAL>.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3476</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> macbook pro
threads.message:
<SIGNAL>SMC_DCIN_VSENSE</SIGNAL> is 2.5v and <SIGNAL>PPDCIN_G3H_ISOL</SIGNAL> is 17.05v
<SIGNAL>PP3V3_S5_AVREF_SMC</SIGNAL> is 3.29

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3476</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> macbook pro
threads.message:
<SIGNAL>SMC_SENSOR_PWR_EN</SIGNAL> only appears in S0 state.
So there should be something else which blocks the SMC in S5 state; could be some bad solders.
Reball SMC; if no result, change it...

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3476</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> macbook pro
threads.message: I have noticed that the SSD gets worm when it's connected to the board and also when it's connected I see that the power supply uses 0.1 amp and when I disconnect the ssd from the board than amperage drops back to 0.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3476</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> macbook pro
threads.message:
Check <SIGNAL>PP3V3_S0SW_SSD_FET</SIGNAL>.
It should not be present in S5 state.
If you get voltage there, change <CHIP>U8070</CHIP>.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3476</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> macbook pro
threads.message:
Could you please help me understanding one thing,
As I understood from your previews explanations 5 volt rail and 3v rail are created by the same component. and an other component ( the SMC i think ) decides which state should become enable ( S5,S4,S3 and S0). Am I correct?
An other thing is that first AL S5 rails must be working than the board can go to the next state I mean without S5 there will be no S4 and S3?
for example if the 5v is present but only in S5 and not present in <SIGNAL>PP5_V5_S3</SIGNAL> than it mean's that there is something on S3 rail gone bad and sends the 5v to the ground or blocks the 5v.

I'm really really great full and appreciate your help and effort.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3476</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> macbook pro
threads.message:
A direct short to ground is easy to confirm; doesn't even need to power up the board.
But a short, or overcurrent, can drop a voltage (S3 for example) only when that power rail is enabled.

Immediately after charger is plugged in, board goes from G3 (mechanical off) state to G2-S5 state.
G2 contains S5 to S0 states.
To exit from S5, <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S5_L</SIGNAL> must be disabled; that means to go high, be aware of _L from the end of name!!!
Many times <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S4_L</SIGNAL> is used instead of S5 one...
Anyone of these signals will let the board in S3 state; also known as Suspend to RAM.
To achieve full working state (S0), <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S3_L</SIGNAL> should go high (disabled).

S4 is known as Suspend to HDD sometime.

BTW, <SIGNAL>5V_S5</SIGNAL> line from MacBooks is a low power line.
5V high power line appears in S4, or S3 state; on the corresponding big coil.
